ã€

#â€‹588 â€” February 6, 2026

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Fiber 3.0: An Express-Inspired Web Framework for Go â€” A web framework inspired by the likes of Nodeâ€™s Express and Rubyâ€™s Sinatra. Built on fasthttp, it offers high performance yet a comfy developer experience. The Whatâ€™s New in v3 guide shows off how significant the release is (itâ€™s the longest release post Iâ€™ve seen!) GitHubÂ repo.

Fenny and Contributors

ğŸ’¡ v3 also addresses some common compatibility complaints with better RFC compliance and support for net/http, fasthttp, and Express-style handlers.

How to Stop Bots from Abusing Free Trials â€” Bots exploit trial signups and drain compute. WorkOS Radar uses device fingerprinting, traffic analysis, and behavioral signals to detect and block abuse in real time while integrating cleanly with your existing auth flow through a simpleÂ API.

WorkOS sponsor

Go's synctest is Amazing â€” The authorâ€™s team tried the new testing/synctest package on a complex part of their app and were surprised by its effectiveness. This post shows off some good use cases, and itâ€™s not just time travel: â€œsynctestâ€™s real advantage is being able to deterministically reason about the ordering of events in aÂ test.â€

Eric Chiang

IN BRIEF:

  • Go 1.26 Release Candidate 3 has been released with a fix for a crypto/tlsÂ bug.

  • Go 1.25.7 is now available. It's an easy bump for 1.25 users focused on small security fixes. Go 1.24.13 was also released covering similarÂ ground.

  • ğŸ¤¯ â–¶ï¸ This example of setting up a co-op experience between a PS2 and Nintendo 64 to play Super Mario 64 is mindboggling. Go plays a small role shuttling USB packets over theÂ network.

Distributing Go Binaries on PyPI Using go-to-wheel â€” Simon shows how you can distribute Go binaries in Python wheels and install them using, say, uvx, bringing the power of Go to Pythonistas (or even just environments focused on Python tooling by default â€“ e.g. sandboxes) without anyÂ fuss.

Simon Willison

â–¶Â Â Manual Memory Management Using jemalloc â€” Take over the job of Go's GC using jemalloc via cgo. A fun, practical demo covering a lot in 11-minutes. You'll learn something, even if only that you don't want to tryÂ it.Â ğŸ˜…

package main

How I Set Up Free Package Vanity URLs with Cloudflare Workers â€” Amine wanted a no-cost vanity URL for his packages (e.g. goâ€¤domainâ€¤com/pkg/name) and Cloudflare Workers offers an idealÂ solution.

Amine Benseddik

Building a JSON Parser in Go with Egg â€” There are already many great JSON parsers out there, but JSON provides a good demonstration for Egg, an expression grammar generator for LL(1) grammars.

Modern C

7 Common IDP Implementation Pitfalls (and How to Avoid Them) â€” Real-world lessons from platform teams on what breaks IDPs in practice and how to fix it before adoptionÂ stalls.

Fairwinds sponsor

ğŸ“º Lessons from Building a Networking Stack for Microcontrollers â€“ Interesting talk from a TinyGo coreÂ maintainer. Patricio Whittingslow

ğŸ“„ Building an In-Memory Cache in Go Using Generics Ganesh Kumar

ğŸ“„ Practical Patterns for Graceful Shutdowns in Go Phuong Le

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

âœ‰ï¸Â msgvault: Local Gmail Download, Archival and Search â€” A tool for archiving and searching emails locally, complete with TUI and MCP server. The ultimate goal? Get off of Gmail entirely. But first, Wes needed a local, live-updated copy of his 39 gigabyteÂ inbox.

Wes McKinney

ğŸ¤–Â yzma 1.7: Perform Local Inference with llama.cpp â€” Run the latest vision and language models locally from Go through llama.cpp with no CGo required (thanks to purego and ffi).

The Hybrid Group

Redka 1.0: Redis Re-Implemented with SQL â€” A Go-powered data store compatible with Redisâ€™s API but that uses SQLite or Postgres as the storage engine. 1.0 is billed as a stable release, but the project has simultaneously gone into â€˜maintenanceÂ modeâ€™.

Anton Zhiyanov

Drift: A Cross-Platform Mobile UI Framework for Go â€” The idea is you write one Go codebase and then build native Android and iOS apps. Itâ€™s early days but a neat idea. The intro has the best overview. GitHubÂ repo.

Drift Contributors

httpx 1.8: A Multi-Purpose HTTP Toolkit for Probing Servers â€” A command line tool, written in Go, for running numerous HTTP â€˜probersâ€™ at the same time using the retryablehttp library under theÂ hood.

Project Discovery

  • Ghostferry 1.2 â€“ Copy data between MySQL instances with minimalÂ downtime.

  • ğŸ¤– Fantasy 0.7 â€“ Build AI agents in Go. Multi-provider and model, oneÂ API.

  • pgstream 1.0 â€“ CLI tool & library for Postgres replication to anyÂ target.

  • Ergo 3.2 â€“ Actor-based framework with zeroÂ dependencies.

  • go-elasticsearch 9.3 â€“ Official Go client forÂ Elasticsearch.

  • nmap 4.0 â€“ Idiomatic Go nmap bindings.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

  • â­ Ben Boyter analyzed 400 million lines of code from GitHub's top repos to quantify how much "boilerplate tax" different languages have (or how "dry" languages are). Go and Rust are much closer than many would suspect.

  • NewsGoat is a Go-powered, terminal-based RSS feed reader with a "vi-like interface". A neat way to keep on top of hundreds of blogs and news sources at once. Our newsletter has an RSS feed tooÂ BTW.

  • Chris Siebenmann shows how most â€œblock localhostâ€ defenses only filter 127.0.0.1 and ::1, but 0.0.0.0 can still hit local services and bypass those checks, though modern browsers are starting to close the hole.

  • GitHub is exploring solutions to tackle low-quality contributions, which could include giving you the option to disable PRs entirely or at least restrict them to collaborators. Got opinions? Join theÂ discussion.

item.title: ã€Run a local Linux environment with a single `go run`ã€‘ä½¿ç”¨å•ä¸ªâ€œgo runâ€è¿è¡Œæœ¬åœ° Linux ç¯å¢ƒ
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹587 â€” January 30, 2026

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

A 'Pure Go' Linux Environment, Inspired by Fabrice Bellard â€” With a single 'go run' you can get a Linux environment up and running using JTâ€™s new project. JT used Claude Code to port Fabrice Bellardâ€™s RISC-V system emulator to Go (not Linux itself, which runs from a specialÂ image). He tells the story (and shares the code) behind how it came together and shares lots of advice (and some of the downsides) for using LLMs in portingÂ projects.

JT Olio

New Course: Backend System Design â€” Join Jem Young for this detailed video course and develop the system-thinking skills to solve complex backend design challenges related to scaling, data storage, reliability, performance, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

ğŸ—£ï¸Â GopherCon 2026 Call for Speakers Now Open â€” The Call for Speakers for GopherCon, taking place this August 3-6 in Seattle, is now open and runs through March 4. A limited number of 'Early Gopher' tickets are also available for the event (28 remain at the time of publication) â€“ see the footer of the homepage forÂ those.

GopherCon

IN BRIEF:

  • Last week we featured Robert Griesemer's proposal for bringing generic methods to Go and there's been a lot of discussion over the past week to catch upÂ on.

  • Damien Neil has written a proposal for adding in-memory implementations of net.Listener, net.Conn, and net.PacketConn to Go. Why? No port exhaustion or other potential 'flakiness' during testing and the ability to inject errors and otherÂ behavior.

  • Nolen Royalty discovered that ssh's keystroke timing obfuscation was flooding his Wish-based game server with ~100 chaff packets per keypress. The fix was forking Go's x/crypto/ssh to stop advertising ping@openssh.com support.

Your Go Tests Probably Don't Need a Mocking Library â€” Redowan explores the argument that many Go testing scenarios can be handled effectively without resorting to full-fledged mocking libraries. He outlines several alternative strategies for isolating code under test, thereby promoting simpler and more idiomaticÂ Go.

Redowan Delowar

Detecting Goroutine Leaks with synctest/pprof in Go 1.26 â€” Go 1.26 is adding a new experimental goroutineleak profile that reports leakedÂ goroutines.

Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ“„ Goodbye Java, Hello Go! â€“ An enterprise development company explains why Go is theirÂ future. Jayasoma and Weerawarana (WSO2)

ğŸ“„ Forcing a Generic Type to Be a Pointer Type (And Some Challenges) Chris Siebenmann

ğŸ“„ How We Built Go-Native Durable Execution Henri Maxime Demoulin (DBOS)

ğŸ“„ Writing a Go SQL database/sql Driver Zach Musgrave (DoltHub)

ğŸ“„ How Tigris Backfilled Its Discord Forum with Go Xe Iaso

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

â™Ÿï¸Â Chess 3: A Chess Engine Written in Go â€” A heavily-optimized UCI-compatible chess engine, focusing on hand-crafted evaluation. The authorâ€™s goal is to create â€œthe strongest golang chess engine in the worldâ€! CLI only but will work with various chess GUIs, and apparently even plays on Lichess sometimes..

Paul Sonkoly

The #1 Time-Series Database Built on Postgres â€” TimescaleDB extends Postgres with hypertables, 95% compression, and continuous aggregates. Start building forÂ free.

Tiger Data sponsor

ğŸ¤–Â Crush v0.36: Charm's Elegant Go Agentic Development Tool â€” Charm continues at full steam ahead with more Crush releases adding Vercel AI Gateway support and a 'crush stats' command to see what's going on with info about token usage, cost, an activity heatmap, and more. If you want a Go-powered Claude Code-a-like that's aesthetically pleasing, give it aÂ spin.

Charm

RegreSQL 1.5: Regression Testing for SQL Queries â€” The idea is simple: take your queries, run them, capture expected results, then on future runs compare when their cost, I/O or other characteristics change. â€œWhen a queryâ€™s result changes unexpectedly, youâ€™ll know immediately.â€ GitHubÂ repo.

boringSQL

Mermaid ASCII: Render Mermaid Graphs in Your Terminal â€” If you want to render Mermaid diagrams like flowcharts and sequence diagrams without having to lean on the JavaScriptÂ ecosystem.

Alexander Grooff

Ristretto: A High Performance Memory-Bound Go Cache â€” Used as part of Dgraph (native GraphQL graph database) but you can use it at a lower level. Think caching database query results, rate limiting,Â etc.

Dgraph

ğŸ¤–Â Bifrost: Go-Powered LLM Gateway Server â€” An open-source LLM gateway optimized for low latency and high throughput, unifying 15+ AI providers behind an OpenAI-compatible API. Think OpenRouter, but on your ownÂ infra.

Maxim AI

  • ğŸ¤– Agent Development Kit (ADK) for Go v0.4 â€“ Google's official Go toolkit for building, evaluating, and deploying AIÂ agents.

  • ğŸ¤– Anthropic Go API v1.20.0 â€“ Official library for using Anthropic's RESTÂ API.

  • fp-go 2.2 â€“ Functional programming primitives and monads.

  • go-github v82.0 â€“ Go client library for the GitHub APIÂ v3.

  • xsync 4.4 â€“ Concurrent data structures forÂ Go.

  • MongoDB Go Driver v2.5.0

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting stories in the broader landscape:

  • Christopher Chedeau explains how he ported 100k lines of TypeScript to Rust using Claude Code. The languages aren't important here, it's more about the insights in nudging agentic tools to get through such mammothÂ tasks.

  • LLM whisperer Simon Willison has discovered ChatGPT can run Go programs (among many other languages) in a sort-of containerized sandbox.

  • OpenAI shares the story of how it's scaled Postgres to serve 800+ million users. The interesting technical point is they're only using a single primary (coupled with many read replicas) to do so.

  • Apple silicon users might be excited to learn Fedora Asahi Remix is now working on the M3. Apple silicon support has been limited to M1s and M2s for some timeÂ now.

item.title: ã€A future for generic methods in Go?ã€‘Go ä¸­æ³›å‹æ–¹æ³•çš„æœªæ¥ï¼Ÿ
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹586 â€” January 23, 2026

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Results from the Latest Go Developer Survey â€” Over 5,000 Go developers responded to the latest official survey, broadly reporting a high level of satisfaction with the language and tooling. Frustrations include difficulty following best practices, missing or disliked features, and trouble finding trustworthy third-party modules. We also learn a little about developers' AIÂ usage.

Todd Kulesza and the Go Team

Query Billions of Rows in Milliseconds â€” Hypertables, 95% compression, continuous aggregates, and 100% Postgres. Query billions of rows in milliseconds. No new query language to learn, no extra infrastructure to manage. Start building forÂ free.

Tiger Data (creators of TimescaleDB) sponsor

A Proposal to Add Generic Methods to Go â€” Itâ€™s early days, but when a proposal arises from one of Goâ€™s co-creators, itâ€™s worth listening! In Go, functions can be generic, but methods cannot, and while generic methods were never intended to be added to Go, â€œperhaps a change of view is inÂ orderâ€.

Robert Griesemer et al.

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ Playdate is an indie, handheld, monochrome gaming device and Roman Bielyi has created Pdgo, an SDK for building Playdate apps inÂ Go.

  • Nature is a general-purpose systems language, heavily inspired by Go and they've released some Nature vs Go performance benchmarks.

  • Microsoft has released its custom builds of Go 1.25.6-1 and 1.24.12-1.

Floating-Point Printing and Parsing Can Be Simple and Fast â€” A fantastically deep and technical tour of implementing some modern floating point number manipulation algorithms in Go. Itâ€™s not just academic, either: â€œI expect some form of this Go code to ship in GoÂ 1.27.â€

Russ Cox

ğŸ˜±Â Panic Recovery â€” Even if you never use panic directly, you still need to know how to recover from panics as they can arise in many ways. Jason covers the basics and shares some gotchas the DoltHub team hasÂ encountered.

Jason Fulghum

Dancing Backwards with Go â€” â€œDancing backwardsâ€ in this context is a playful framing for TDD, and John skips through this example with the grace of GingerÂ Rogers.

John Arundel

ğŸ“„ Patching the Wii News Channel to Serve Local News in 2025 â€“ Delightfully niche and a fun use forÂ Go. RaÃºl NegrÃ³n

ğŸ“„ A Rust Developer's Honest Review of Go â€“ A developer who has been using Go for a few months shares what he does and doesnâ€™tÂ like. Ben Raz

ğŸ“„ Writing a Time Series Database from Scratch in Go â€“ A slide deck. Aliaksandr Valialkin (VictoriaMetrics)

ğŸ“„ On Starting to Write a Compiler in Go Uros Popovic

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Google's JSON Schema Package for Go â€” Two members of the Go team introduce us to a comprehensive JSON Schema package Google uses in the official Go SDK for MCP. JSON Schema provides a way to describe the shape of JSON values, so values can be generated or validated to the spec. GitHubÂ repo.

Amsterdam and Thanawalla

Deploy Your Services Anywhere with Cloud 66 â€” Run APIs on your cloud of choice with Kubernetes orchestration and full control over builds &Â clusters.

Cloud 66 sponsor

go-quickjs-wasi-reactor: Run QuickJS Efficiently Under Go â€” Run the WASM-based NG fork of the embeddable QuickJS JavaScript engine directly within your Go app. Uses an approach that lets you step through the JS event loop manually, if you like, and poll for IOÂ yourself.

Aperture Robotics

GopherJS 1.20: A Go to JavaScript Transpiler â€” Provides the opportunity to write front-end code in Go and run it in the browser sans WebAssembly. Thereâ€™s an online playground if you want to have a quick play. v1.20 brings things up to Go 1.20.14Â standards.

GopherJS

mactop: A Terminal Based Monitoring Tool for Apple Silicon â€” A Mac-specific top-a-like that shows off real-time CPU and GPU usage, along with metrics about power and memoryÂ usage.

Carsen Klock

  • Echo 5.0 â€“ Popular extensible high performance web framework. A maintenance release but with major breakingÂ changes.

  • âœ‰ï¸ Notifuse v26 â€“ Self-hosted emailing platform for sending and designing newsletters and transactional emails. AGPL licensed.

  • ğŸ¤– grepai 0.21.0 â€“ Index code using vector embeddings and use natural language queries to find conceptually relatedÂ code.

  • Google API Linter v2.2 â€“ Real-time checks for compliance with Google's API standards on protocol buffer-defined API surfaces.

  • Sonic 1.15 â€“ High performance JSON serialization and deserialization library accelerated by JIT andÂ SIMD.

  • ğŸ¤– Crush v0.34.0 â€“ The Charm team's terminal-based AI coding assistant.

  • GoProxy 1.8 â€“ Library for creating custom HTTP/HTTPS proxy servers.

  • Postgresus 3.5 â€“ Backup tool for Postgres, MySQL andÂ MongoDB.

  • pgmetrics v1.19 â€“ Collect and display metrics from PostgresÂ servers.

  • Telego 1.5 â€“ Telegram Bot APIÂ library.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting stories in the broader landscape:

  • ğŸ¤– Esteemed coder Steve Yegge is up to some interesting stuff with Gas Town, a sort of large scale, multi-agent orchestration system for Claude Code, all built in Go. Tim Sehn has written a bit more about itÂ here.

  • ğŸ” The VS Code team explains how they implemented a new, fast client-side docs search system for the VS Code site using WebAssembly. You can use their docfind engine for yourself too, and there's a live demo showing off how fast it is over an index of 50,000Â articles.

  • ğŸ˜ Postgres users might enjoy this article about alternatives to 'soft delete' where rather than use a boolean or datetime flag, you could use a trigger to move a row to an archive table or capture deleted rows from the WAL forÂ archival.

  • A look at the state of WebAssembly in 2025 and 2026.

item.title: ã€Go 1.26 RC2, Go 1.25.6, and Go 1.24.12 releasedã€‘Go 1.26 RC2ã€Go 1.25.6 å’Œ Go 1.24.12 å‘å¸ƒ
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹585 â€” January 16, 2026

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Go 1.26 Release Candidate 2 Released â€” Go 1.26 gets a little closer to its final release in a few weeks with a fresh release candidate including several security fixes in areas like archive/zip and Request.ParseForm. "Run it in dev! Run it in prod! File bugs!" says the Go team. The draft release notes remain a good way to get up to speed, as does Anton Zhiyanovâ€™s Go 1.26 interactiveÂ tour.

Junyang and Michael for the Go team

ğŸ’¡ Go 1.25.6 and Go 1.24.12 have also been released including the same security fixes asÂ 1.26rc2Â above.

Give Us Your Tired, Your Restless, Your Micromanaged, Yearning to Build Freely ğŸ—½ â€” Fluidstack is hiring across 50+ infrastructure and engineering roles across the country. If you want to drive deployments for frontier labs, experience real autonomy, and build the AI infrastructure our future will rely on, check out all our open positions.Â ğŸš€

Fluidstack sponsor

Are Atomic Operations Faster & Better Than a Mutex? It Depends â€” While atomic operations can be significantly faster than mutexes, that speed comes with trade-offs in complexity and correctness that often make mutexes the betterÂ choice.

Benjamin Cane

Writing Mutexes From Scratch in Go â€” Experimenting with other options to implement locks that are lower level than just relying on sync.Mutex.

Chris Rybicki

Stop Overthinking Struct Pointer and Value Semantics in Go â€” When creating a struct type, you can face decisions about whether to use value or pointer semantics. Rather than debating this case-by-case, why not establish aÂ convention?

Preslav Rachev

ğŸ“„ 'Losing' 1Â½ Million Lines of Go â€“ Tim looks at the complexity of adding up-to-date Unicode support to Quamina, a pure Go pattern matching library heâ€™s workingÂ on. Tim Bray

ğŸ“„ Porting MiniJinja to Go with an Agent â€“ MiniJinja is a Rust-powered Jinja2 templateÂ engine. Armin Ronacher

ğŸ“„ Finding and Fixing a 50,000 Goroutine Leak That Nearly Killed Production â€“ Serge spotted a hidden killer goroutine leak that had been growing for sixÂ weeks. Serge Skoredin

ğŸ“„ Racing with Disaster: Data Races in Go John Arundel

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

godump 1.9: A Pretty-Printer and Debug Dumper for Structs â€” Inspired by a similar feature in Laravel, this library lets you print structs, slices, maps, and more, in an easy to read fashion at the terminal. v1.9 adds optional field retraction, but other recent releases have added other niceties like diff support, HTML output, and a builder-style API for heavyÂ customization.

Chris Miles

Notify 1.5: Send Notifications to Various Messaging Services â€” Supports about thirty different services including Discord, AWS SES and SNS, Microsoft Teams, Slack, andÂ Telegram.

Niko KÃ¶ser

How Teams Add Leverage to Their Kubernetes Environments â€” If k8s isnâ€™t your product, why treat it like one? Learn what to own, what to outsource, and how to stay inÂ control.

Fairwinds sponsor

libgodc: A Go Runtime for the Sega Dreamcast â€” The Dreamcast, released in 1999, was Segaâ€™s last truly innovative console (with a whole 16MB of RAM and a 200MHz CPU!) and, amazingly, you can now build things for it with Go, complete with support for goroutines, channels, garbage collection, etc. The project even includes some games as examples, such as a Pong clone. Thereâ€™s extensive documentation too.

Panagiotis Georgiadis et al.

go-astiav: ffmpeg Bindings for Go â€” The goal is to provide a more idiomatically Go API for FFmpegâ€™s various multimedia features. Now supports FFmpegÂ 8.

Quentin Renard

parse-dmarc: A Lightweight, Self-hosted DMARC Report Parser â€” DMARC is an email authentication standard used, in part, to prevent email address spoofing. There are numerous services that can collect and collate DMARC reports for you, but this gives you a single binary solution complete with a Vue-poweredÂ frontend.

Meysam

  • Chroma 2.22 â€“ Pygments-inspired general purpose syntax highlighter in pureÂ Go. There's an online playground if you want to give it aÂ spinÂ (above).

  • Warp v1.4 â€“ S3 benchmarking tool supporting concurrent operations, multiple hosts, and distributed testing.

  • AWS Lambda for Go v1.52.0 â€“ Libraries, samples and tools that help Go developers build AWS Lambda functions.

  • Terratest v0.55.0 â€“ Library for writing automated tests for infrastructureÂ code.

  • River 0.30 â€“ Fast & reliable Postgres-powered background jobsÂ system.

  • hcloud v2.35.0 â€“ Official Go library for the Hetzner CloudÂ API.

  • quic-go 0.59 â€“ Pure Go QUICÂ implementation.

  • Air 1.64 â€“ Live reload for GoÂ apps.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting stories in the broader landscape:

  • There's a surprisingly large ecosystem of retro Windows users and developers, and both go-legacy-win7 and go-legacy-winxp make it possible to compile Go programs for Windows 7 and Windows XPÂ respectively.

  • ğŸ¤– Even Linus Torvalds is 'vibe coding' now. He's been using Google's Antigravity tool to create some digital soundÂ effects.

  • goscript is a curious, experimental tool that translates Go code to TypeScript at the AST level so you can share algorithms and business logic between your Go backend and TypeScriptÂ frontend.

  • ğŸ“˜ The Concise TypeScript Book is a short, focused TypeScript guide that's open and free toÂ read.

  • Artem Golubin suggests you probably don't need Oh My Zsh.
